name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: @Zeeshan44648323 @iamshack24 OK, here it is: With $NNDM management apparently willing to blow shareholder money on their buddies' businesses, the cash on its balance sheet doesn't deserve to be valued at par. Worthless core technology + cash wasted on bad deals = more downside ahead 6/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: $NNDM boards also can't stand up to the high temperatures used in standard reflow ovens to solder on electronic components, forcing these components to be painstakingly soldered by hand ‚Äì another massive inefficiency. It's bad technology. 3/3

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: A former $NNDM employee told us that the company's silver-based conductive "ink" usually only lasted for a short time before it oxidized and became useless, leading to a need for multiple copies of a single prototype ‚Äì very inefficient. 2/3

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Re: $NNDM, a few tidbits from our research: one person with direct experience using the company's machines told us that output quality was so bad that sometimes if you just *picked up* a printed board, it would stop working. 1/3

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: With $NNDM management apparently willing to blow shareholder money on their buddies' businesses, the cash on its balance sheet doesn't deserve to be valued at par. Worthless core technology + cash wasted on bad deals = more downside ahead 6/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Stripping away the buzzwords, what's really happening is that $NNDM is using shareholder money to buy out an obscure, unrelated start-up founded by two of its board members. It's hard to see how this isn't pure self-dealing. 5/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Look at the gibberish here: "DeepCube‚Äôs AI/ML/DL 'brain'...is expected to manage a neural network of edge devices, self-learning and self-improving their efficacy and self-managing and maximizing yield throughout the total network." 4/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: But $NNDM capitalized on market craziness to raise a ludicrous amount of cash (~$1.5B), w/no obvious use. Now it's writing a big check to acquire a company that has nothing to do with 3D printing, founded by two of its board members...?! 3/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: $NNDM's core concept is itself a joke: it's supposed to allow 3D printing of circuit boards, but its tech can't handle high temperatures or produce boards with high conductivity. Early adopters have been very disappointed w/the results. 2/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: We‚Äôre short $NNDM. The deal $NNDM announced today to acquire "DeepCube" is one of the silliest moves in recent memory: paying $70mm to acquire a random start-up in an unrelated field founded by two of $NNDM's board members! 1/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: $PLUG: Podcast (with live comments) beginning now via link below (Twitter) or via youtube at  https://t.co/OOLUXgMySz

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: $PLUG: Will respond to comments/questions in Q&A of @SeekingAlpha article. Trolling aside, there's a good discussion to be had on future of hydrogen vs batteries. And forklift power sources.

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: The rosy prospect of a meaningful hydrogen energy ecosystem embedded in $PLUG's valuation is entirely divorced from a reality in which Plug really just sells niche fuel cells to customers indirectly compensated for buying them. $PLUG isn‚Äôt worth $1b, let alone $40b (9/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Finally, Plug's recent deals with SK Group & Renault have propelled shares recently. But these deals emerge from the inherent weaknesses of SK, a conglomerate in a country reliant on others for fossil fuels, and Renault, which is playing catch-up in EVs. (8/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Meanwhile, >70% of forklift revenue is from just 2 customers: Amazon and Walmart, who are incentivized to buy Plug equipment in return for cheap $PLUG warrants, the value of which is now $5.5B. Nice payoff for buttressing Plug‚Äôs efforts to pretend it has a viable business. (7/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: YET PLUG IS TRADING AT $40BN!! WTF! If you want to rebel against @elonmusk (and every veteran of the renewable space) and play hydrogen roulette, there‚Äôs $BLDP at $10bn and $FCEL at $6bn. Both are also massively overvalued, but they‚Äôre deep value stocks compared to $PLUG (6/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: $PLUG's sales come from fuel cells & refueling infrastructure for forklifts, yet in a preview of H2's futility, Li-batteries conquered ~20% of the mkt in just 3 yrs vs FCs at <2%! There's no economic case for H2 versus Li-batteries, even in the one niche Plug is focused on. (5/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: There's no S-curve for hydrogen to climb to compete with solar- and wind-powered electricity & batteries. The laws of physics mean that hydrogen will *never* make sense in comparison. Widescale use of the electrolyzers and fuel cells made by PLUG is a delusional fantasy. (4/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: The world will *never* meaningfully use "green" hydrogen for energy. It's too expensive and inefficient to make, store, transport, and use. Just ask @elonmusk:  https://t.co/fqUY3gDnqT. Li-batteries are better in nearly all use cases & their superiority grows each year (3/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Valued at an absurd $40b, PLUG is a forklift power-source maker that makes the worst forklift power sources in the market. The stock has become a beneficiary of the hopes, dreams, and delusions of the green hydrogen energy movement, but the "Hydrogen Economy" is a mirage (2/9)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: We're short $PLUG. Report at  https://t.co/DzuSaER4oL. We discuss with @grizzlemedia at 1:30 at  https://t.co/pbanbMN0nP. Plug isn't a way to bet on the overhyped ‚Äúhydrogen economy‚Äù; it‚Äôs just a /r/wallstreetbets roach motel where your fellow travelers probably failed HS chemistry

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: With few products, fewer customers, and sales stalling, $TTCF has garnered a valuation of ~13x branded revenue sales, far in excess of even the hottest "plant-based" concepts. We think the stock is worth less than half its current price. (6/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: The concentration is a reflection of $TTCF's weaknesses: dearth of innovation, meager product assortment, and lack of merchandising competence makes wholesale clubs the only attainable sales channel and virtually ensures the failure to penetrate the grocer channel. (5/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: In-depth interviews with $TTCF customers indicate a dangerous degree of concentration risk. We estimate >70% of $TTCF branded sales go to one customer ‚Äì Sam's Club ‚Äì and ~75% of *that* is just 4-5 products. (4/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: In reality, $TTCF sales strength early this year was mostly due to pandemic-related pantry-loading in the first quarter, which also artificially boosted profitability. In the last two quarters, though, gross margins tanked, and sales momentum stalled. (3/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Nielsen data show $TTCF retail sales stalling. Frozen food sales usually bottom in summer and rise into fall/winter. But Tattooed Chef retail sales in recent months are *lower* than summer levels, underperforming other emerging brands (e.g., @CAULIPOWER, @daiyafoods). (2/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: We're short $TTCF. Report available at  https://t.co/73LHDWwGN5. Collapsing sales growth, elusive profitability, customer concentration at cost-conscious Sam‚Äôs Club, thin product set, poor branding all point to a low-multiple biz, contrary to what reddit pajama traders claim 1/6

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: With a history of generating neither profits nor cashflow, and its hopes for growth dashed, the relentless technological improvement of catheter ablation threatens the very existence of $ATRC. (6/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Meanwhile, Atricure's core business ‚Äì concomitant surgical ablation ‚Äì is almost totally saturated. Clinical data suggest a TAM a third of the size ATRC claims that's >80% penetrated. The result is a core business whose growth has hit a wall. (5/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: At the same time, new technologies like pulsed field ablation and real-time mapping (from e.g. @farapulse and @AcutusMedical) dramatically improve the safety, speed, and efficacy of CA. Stand alone surgical ablation procedures like Convergent will be completely obsolete. (4/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: EPs are unmoved by results of CONVERGE, a trial designed in 2013, which compares Convergent with a CA that doesn't even apply the same lesions. They know modern CA techniques can match Convergent and are skeptical of referring patients for a riskier surgical procedure. (3/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Convergent is doomed to fail. Studies consistently show that modern catheter ablation (CA) technology allows electrophysiologists to create the Convergent lesion-sets more safely and effectively in their lab than in the operating room. (2/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: We're short $ATRC. Report available at  https://t.co/eDQtYP2gcx.  AtriCure trades at close to the highest valuation in its history, as investors assume widespread adoption of the Convergent procedure and continued growth in surgical devices. Both assumptions are misplaced. (1/6)

name: Kerrisdale Capital

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: At more than $4.5bn, Mirati's valuation assumes great clinical success & maybe some M&A. But the future of its 2 drugs is bleaker than ever, not to mention G12C competition & 2nd-gen KRASi looming. At best $MRTX is worth a fraction of $4.5bn. At worst, it's a zero. (8/8)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Mirati's other drug, sitravatinib, has shown zero single-agent activity. And the attempt to combine with checkpoint inhibition in checkpoint-refractory patients is just ridiculous. How else to describe weak Ph2 data, absurd endpoint estimates, and 2 years with no updates? (7/8)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Meanwhile, combo attempt w/checkpoint inhibitors is based on shoddy preclinical work: shrinking a mouse tumor model w/no resemblance to human NSCLC. Plus, KRAS mutants are already vulnerable to CPIs and trying to enhance that effect is futile. MRTX-849 is bound to fail. (6/8)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Heterogeneity of KRAS mutations also means targeted therapy combinations with '849 are a roll of the dice. There's no way to know when to use which combo, and biomarkers that could help don't exist. (5/8)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Preclinical research reveals high rates of primary resistance and/or rapid adaptive resistance to G12Ci: KRAS-mutant cancers don't always depend on the KRAS mutation and those that do have multiple pathways to resist KRAS-knockdown. Thus, low response rates, short DORs. (4/8)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Meanwhile, data on '849 in NSCLC consists of 5 patients w/longest DOR at 10 weeks. It's been >6 months since the last data update from Mirati. The silence is deafening. (3/8)

name: Kerrisdale Capital
tweet: Excitement over '849 is mostly based on data for Amgen's KRASi, which has an identical MOA & more extensive data. But over time, Amgen's data has deteriorated. Response rates keep coming down, and response durations are short. Odds of accelerated approval are remote. (2/8)
